title: Hemis Monastery
summary: Hemis Monastery is a significant Himalayan Buddhist monastery of the Drukpa Lineage, located in Hemis, Ladakh, India, on the bank of the Indus River. Re-established in 1672 by King Sengge Namgyal, it is renowned for its annual Hemis festival dedicated to Padmasambhava. The monastery gained controversial attention in the late 19th and early 20th centuries due to claims by Nicolas Notovitch and Swami Abhedananda of a manuscript, 'Life of Saint Issa', alleging Jesus's travels to India during his 'lost years'. These claims are widely regarded by historians as fabricated hoaxes.
key_points: Hemis Monastery is a Himalayan Buddhist gompa of the Drukpa Lineage, located in Ladakh, India.
It was re-established in 1672 by the Ladakhi king Sengge Namgyal.
The monastery hosts the annual Hemis festival in early June, honoring Padmasambhava.
It was at the center of a historical controversy concerning the alleged discovery of the 'Life of Saint Issa' manuscript by Nicolas Notovitch in 1894, which is widely considered a hoax.
Swami Abhedananda also claimed to have read the same manuscript in 1921, further fueling the legend.
The monastery features a gallery with paintings of the Eighty-Four Mahasiddhas.
timeline: Before 11th century: Hemis Monastery already existed.
1672: Re-established by the Ladakhi king Sengge Namgyal.
1894: Russian journalist Nicolas Notovitch claimed to discover 'Life of Saint Issa' manuscript at Hemis.
1921: Indian Pandit Swami Abhedananda claimed to have read the same manuscript.
Early June (annually): Hemis festival honouring Padmasambhava is held.
important_figures: Sengge Namgyal (Ladakhi king who re-established the monastery)
Padmasambhava (honoured at the annual Hemis festival)
Nicolas Notovitch (Russian journalist, author of the controversial 'Life of Saint Issa')
Swami Abhedananda (Indian Pandit who also claimed to read the manuscript)
Bart D. Ehrman (Bible scholar who debunks Notovitch's claims)
applications: Site for Buddhist religious worship and spiritual practice
Center for the preservation of Himalayan Buddhist culture and Drukpa Lineage traditions
Major pilgrimage and tourism destination in Ladakh, India
current_status: Hemis Monastery remains an active and significant Himalayan Buddhist monastery of the Drukpa Lineage, drawing numerous pilgrims and tourists annually. It continues to host its traditional festivals and uphold Buddhist practices.
future_prospects: The monastery is expected to maintain its importance as a spiritual and cultural hub in Ladakh, potentially seeing continued growth in religious tourism and pilgrimage. There will likely be ongoing efforts for the preservation of its historical architecture, art, and traditions.
